description.narrative:
Ambassaden har bedömt att Population Services International (PSI) har god kapacitet och möjlighet att genomföra projektet Stopping Abuse and Female Exploitation (SAFE) i Zimbabwe under perioden 2020-2021 och PSI har därför tilldelats 30 miljoner SEK från Sida för detta ändamål.
Insatsen syftar till att skydda kvinnor och barn i Zimbabwe från de allra allvarligaste formerna av våld, inklusive barnäktenskap, könsrelaterat våld, och modernt slaveri, genom en nationell social kampanj. Målen med insatsen är att 1) förebygga könsrelaterat våld, inklusive barnaga och barnäktenskap; 2) ändra beteenden och attityder i syfte att skapa positivt föräldraskap och minska våld i hemmet, på skolor och på arbetsplatsen; 3) använda innovativa metoder för att engagera olika nyckelaktörer och "influencers" till att agera som nationella förebilder; 4) och öka medvetenheten om, och kopplingar till, tillgängliga tjänster för överlevande av könsrelaterat våld genom en riskhanteringsstrategi.
Insatsens totala budget är 30 miljoner SEK över två år. Cirka 1 miljon SEK kommer att vidareförmedlas till organisationen InterNews - en partner som Ambassaden stödjer i en pågående insats - som implementerar kapacitetsbyggande åtgärder för journalister kring ansvarsfull rapportering om könsrelaterat våld, aga och barnäktenskap. Ambassadens pågående samarbete med InterNews syftar till att stärka och kapacitetsutveckla den oberoende mediasektorn främst inom användandet av digital media för att nå ut till kvinnor och unga, och PSI kommer att använda sig av detta samarbete inom ramen för SAFE för att skapa synergier mellan de två insatserna och undvika duplicering.
Den nationella sociala kampanjen är en separat komponent av tre komponenter i SAFE programmet där DFID finansierar de resterande två. Dessa består av en komponent som syftar till prevention och respons på lokal nivå, och en komponent kring utvärdering och lärande som också innefattar en utvärdering av den Sida-finansierade komponenten. Även om den nationella sociala kampanjen är fristående så är det viktigt att belysa att PSI och Sida kommer att vara en del av styrgruppen för hela programmet tillsammans med DFID och deras implementerande partner Ecorys.
Ambassaden bedömer att insatsen är relevant för vår strategi, huvudsakligen vad gäller område 1.3, men också områden 2.1 och 2.2.

Population Services International (PSI) has applied to Sida for funding of 30 million SEK to carry out "Stopping Abuse and Female Exploitation (SAFE)" which aims to protect women and children in Zimbabwe from the most severe forms of violence, including child marriage, GBV and modern slavery. This is a national-level social communications campaign to reduce gender-based violence and is aligned to Sweden's Development Cooperation strategy with Zimbabwe 2017-2021. The objectives of the contribution are to prevent GBV, including corporal punishment directed at girls and boys, and child marriage; change behaviors and attitudes in order to enhance positive parenting and reduce violence in homes, schools and at the workplace; use innovative approaches and methods to engage different stakeholders and influencers to become rolemodels nationwide; and increase awareness of and linkages to available services for survivors of GBV in a risk management approach.

The intervention's impact is reduced incidence of gender-based violence in Zimbabwe by 2021. The purpose of the intervention is to prevent GBV, including corporal punishment directed at girls and boys, child marriage, to change behaviours and attitudes to reduce violence in homes, schools and at the workplace, and to increase awareness of available services for GBV survivors. PSI proposes a national branded campaign that will support women and girls to understand their human rights; engage male peers to act as inherent change makers; improve gender equality; and increase the number of men and women who believe GBV should not be tolerated in their communities. PSI will leverage existing structures by working together with the FCDO supported SAFE program, once launched, the GoZ, and other implementing partners including the EU-funded Spotlight initiative, DREAMS, and other Sweden, FCDO and PEPFAR-funded implementers. The campaign will be designed using a feminist focus and human rights perspective, and will use evidence-based and HCD-informed approaches to develop messaging to achieve four primary objectives: 1) prevent GBV, including corporal punishment directed at girls and boys, and child marriage; 2) change behaviors and attitudes in order to enhance positive parenting and reduce violence in homes, schools and at the workplace; 3) use innovative approaches and methods to engage different stakeholders and influencers to become rolemodels nationwide; and 4) increase awareness of and linkages to available services for survivors of GBV in a risk management approach. The objectives will be reached through a range of activities like integrating GBV messages through "brand ambassadors" in existing DREAMS programme, building national champions (celebrities, influencers, girls and women/men and boys) through various platforms where their message can be shared, capacitating media to report responsibly and accurately on GBV issues, using a "green card initiative" to celebrate men who exemplify positive gender norms, and many other activities. The campaign will target five primary population groups through tailored approaches to achieve the campaign objectives: Children and Adolescents Students, Out-of-school Adolescent Girls and Boys, Adult Women, Adult Men, Family Unit. Essential stakeholders and influencers will form secondary target audiences of the campaign, including perpetrators of GBV, educational, political, and religious leaders due to their critical influence over target beneficiaries. A key component of the strategic approach will be to work in close coordination with existing community-level activities in Zimbabwe. The project´s national campaign will complement community level work with mass and community messaging to sensitize, mobilize, and create stakeholder and influencer champions that are willing to stand up as role models and allies, and vocalize their intolerance of gender inequality and GBV.

sector.narrative: Ending violence against women and girls

tag.narrative: 16.2 - Eliminera övergrepp, utnyttjande, människohandel och alla former av våld eller tortyr mot barn.
16.2 - End abuse, exploitation, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

3.8 - Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.

3.8 - Åstadkomma allmän hälso- och sjukvård för alla, som även skyddar mot ekonomisk risk, tillgång till grundläggande hälso- och sjukvård av god kvalitet liksom tillgång till säkra, effektiva och ekonomiskt överkomliga grundläggande läkemedel och vaccin av god kvalitet.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.3 - Avskaffa alla skadliga sedvänjor, såsom barnäktenskap, tidiga äktenskap och tvångsäktenskap samt kvinnlig könsstympning.
5.3 - Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.
5.b - Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.
5.b - Öka användningen av gynnsam teknik, i synnerhet informations- och kommunikationsteknik, för att främja kvinnors egenmakt
5.c - Adopt and strengthen sound policies and enforceable legislation for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls at all levels.
5.c - Anta och stärka välgrundad politik och genomförbar lagstiftning för att främja jämställdhet och öka alla kvinnors och flickors egenmakt på alla nivåer

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The narrative report was submitted on time in line with the agreed conditions. The reporting year was mainly for campaign formulation and included literature review, getting the Research Ethics Board approval for the Human Centred Design work, recruiting immersions participants and conducting the immersions in 6 districts. The work was divided into the formative work, insights gathering and field work, data synthesis\theme development, stakeholder engagement and campaign development. The advent of Covid-19 and the subsequent lockdown measures and restrictions resulted in delays in programme implementation. The Embassy had dialogues with PSI on programme modifications and a revised workplan was adopted. The Covid-19 restrictions resulted in some data collection and data synthesis processes being done using virtual platforms. The virtual processes took longer time as compared to the physical. The delays in implementation resulted in the contribution utilising SEK 2,084,500 of the SEK15 000 000. The Embassy had discussions around budget utilisation in 2020 which resulted in the Embassy amending the dirsbursement for the other PSI SRHR programme so that it utilises the cash on hand from SAFE. The SAFE programme had to undergo a decoupling process as some components under FCDO were put on hold due to Covid-19. Processes conducted Formative work This workstream centred on reviewing the literature to inform the problem definition activity and to shape the protocol for the Human Centred Design field work activities. Sensitisation meetings were also conducted with the Ministry of Women Affairs, Ministry of Health, UN Agencies, and Civil Society to share the vision of the campaign. Insights gathering fieldwork Medical Research Council of Zimbabwe and PSI Research Ethics Board approval of the protocol was granted in August 2020. Data gathering was conducted in the selected 6 rural & urban districts (Mbare, Chikomba, Bindura, Mwenezi, Bulawayo, Mangwe). These districts were selected for the Human Centred Design field work due to their high prevalence of intimate partner violence and a gap in service coverage. Data synthesis, analysis, and theme development Due to Covid-19 restrictions, the program adapted a virtual workshops format to conduct data analysis using mural applications online. This process proved to be very slow compared to the usual face to face workshops and took over 2 months (Oct – Nov) to complete. Key themes around the triggers for violence and motivators to behaviour change were identified. User personas (archetypes) that best represented the unique characteristics of the different categories of perpetrators, champions, survivors, and influencers were identified. Campaign Development The initial design of the campaign was to have a three-pronged campaign to reduce Intimate Partner Violence, corporal punishment and child marriages. However, data gathering insights revealed a strong link between corporal punishment among boys in childhood and intimate partner violence in adulthood. The insights also revealed that child marriage is a deeply entrenched problem which needs a standalone insight gathering process and campaign to unravel its underlying causes and drivers. Child marriage will need a campaign on its own.The campaign is therefore focusing on two prongs, corporal punishment, and intimate partner violence. The Embassy, if funding is available will have dialogue with PSI for a follow up campaign focusing on child marriages. Lessons learnt Flexibility and quick adaptation are key to counter unanticipated threats – Many challenges and delays faced by the program during the year were due to Covid-19. Dialogues between the Embassy and PSI resulted in quick adaptation and workplan modifications that allowed the program to coordinate and conclude the insights gathering which formed the basis for the national branded campaign development. Engaging line Ministries national and sub-national teams at the formative stages of the campaign – The campaign formulation benefited from the engagement of line ministries like the Ministry of Women Affairs who have a strong presence in the districts. This enabled the recruitment of the right profile of perpetrators and survivors who are often hard to reach. Selection of creative agencies could have been done better- Procurement delays and failure to identify experienced local agencies can be avoided by conducting snapshot analysis of local capacity before flighting tenders. Child marriage should be addressed separately in a standalone campaign: Following the literature review and during Human Centered Design planning and insight gathering, it became apparent that child marriages was a whole program on its own with many dimensions to it. The recommendation is to have child marriages to be addressed as a standalone campaign in the following year.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
